economic_context.details: Multiple disputes centered on Mengin's role as village herdsman: refusing to pay 'les vins' (customary payment), disputes over grain payments, conflicts over woodland fines payment for herdsman position, payment disputes for carting work, disputes over compensation for crop damage. Economic hardship mentioned - Mengin lamenting his poverty when devil approached him. Loss of herdsman position was central economic issue leading to many conflicts. Confessed to thefts driven by poverty: 2 loaves at Vic 18 years earlier, a sheep on lease from Pieron George of Champenoux (killed 5 years before), shoes for 12-year-old daughter at Vic 3 years before.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a comprehensive trial record with detailed witness testimonies following a clear pattern: long reputation for witchcraft + specific quarrel/conflict + harm befalling witness or their property shortly after. The accused was a village herdsman whose loss of this position and related economic disputes drove most of the conflicts. The trial shows the legal process backfiring - Mengin sought redress for defamation but the accused chose to become partie formelle, leading to full witchcraft prosecution. Confession came only under torture and included standard elements: devil pact, powders, sabbat attendance. Named one accomplice at execution. Clear economic tensions around customary payments and herdsman position. Total of 20 witnesses with varying levels of specific testimony (some reputation only). Trial lasted 23 days from informations preparatoires to execution.
